item.description:
How to play!

Social Sabotage gameplay is simple. There are two types of cards:

Where cards, which give the destination for your message, picture, or caption.

 Post on a family member's Facebook profile...
 Post on Facebook...
 Send an ex...




and What cards, which provide awkward messages, pictures or captions you’ll need to send.

 I love the smell of my own farts!
 Grandpa really fills out those khakis.




Players take turns challenging one another with combinations of What and Where cards.

 Post on Facebook... I love the smell of my own farts!




The player with the courage to collect the most Where cards and What cards earns the most points. That’s how you win.

—description from the publisher

Lunar 5000 a future based evolution of the Indy 500 races. Players start by constructing a race ship consisting of one engine and a variety of parts. Generally the engines give a big boost to speed and the parts have abilities that do a variety of other things like manipulating dice, hindering other pilots, and much more. With over 26 Engines and 60 parts there are lots of combinations to try out.

The second part of the game is the race itself. Once the pilots have completed building they will take off. The race is driven by players rolling 2 types of dice, engine dice which are numbered 1-6 to determine a ships speed and the pilot die which corresponds to one of the 6 pilot colors giving the rolled pilots ship a bonus.

High tensions will rise in this head to head all out race to the finish line. When the dice hit the table will you be in the winners circle?
-description from designer

For centuries, the citizens of the Cupcake Kingdom have lived peacefully in a delicious dessert utopia. They've done so side-by-side with fantastical fauna, creatures with a cavernous craving for the choicest of cupcakes. Using sweet treats with the perfect blend of sugar, spice, and everything nice for each species, monster trainers befriend and tame these wild beasts. Feed them too many cupcakes at once, though, and they won't get the sugar rush they crave...but a terrible tummyache instead!

In Creatures and Cupcakes, monster trainers compete to tame two magical creatures to show off to the Cupcake King and Cupcake Queen. The trainer who does this first wins.

In this press-your-luck game, players pull cupcakes out of a bag. Every cupcake you draw advances you a space on each creature's affection track. However, if you draw two of the same in a row, your turn ends immediately. Even going bust has its sweet rewards as that player will get either a special power card with a one-time effect or a medicine card to help keep that monster from overeating next time.

—description from the publisher

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

item.description:
Ascent The Game of Rocketry is a competitive card game that sets two to four players into the world of rocket building. The game takes heavy inspiration from the Space Race and every rocket, card and patch is steeped with history.

Players take turns testing one of their systems, while the other players try to play Fail cards to damage the system and can keep it from passing. Players, however, can repair their own systems mid-test by playing OK cards, based on Mission Control Officers and Engineers. The first player to have all 4 of his or her systems survive testing, completes a rocket, earns a Mission Patch and ends the round.

Players can collect Mission Patches along the way for various in-game achievements (including completing a Rocket) and the player with the most patches at the end of 3 rounds wins the game! Mission Patches are used as a scoring mechanism as well as granting special rules to the players that hold them, creating a dynamic system that adds an ever-shifting asymmetrical gameplay landscape, keeping players on their toes and deepening the strategy further.

You’re living the dream. You’re in a band and they’re about to go on tour. It’s your job to schedule the band’s stops over your 100-day tour, visiting as many states as possible.

Each turn two ten-sided dice are rolled to make two 2-digit numbers. For example, a roll of 3 and 7 creates the numbers 37 and 73.

All players write each of those numbers in a state on their map. The regions they can write in are restricted by three cards turned up in the middle of the table.

At the end of the game, each player draws a route on their map, starting with a low number and visiting adjacent states with higher and higher numbers. Players get a point for every state they visit.

There are also some bonus points available, a way to get wilds, and a variable setup step that makes every game different.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Jester’s Court, Suit Thyself! is a 2 to 4 player game for ages 9 and up. It has unique movement and competitive mechanics with subtle degrees of luck and strategy. Using cards, players maneuver their Mage on a grid and attack other players to weaken their avatars and eventually cause them to lose some of the suits they’ve collected. Blocking stones may also be placed, and players may also take steps to heal their Mage.

The print version of Jester’s Court, Suit Thyself! includes the following components:


 4 Wooden Pawns in 4 colors (Mages)
 4 Wooden Columns in 4 colors (Menhir Blocking Stones)
 20 Health & Suit Tokens in 4 colors
 4 Mage Reference cards
 4 Six-sided dice in 4 colors
 1 18” x 18” Quad-Fold Game Board
 Rule Booklet


The 4 colors are Red, Green, Blue, and Yellow.

In addition to the included components, you will need two standard decks of playing cards. These are standard poker decks including two jokers per deck of cards. For 2 player games, use 1 deck of cards with 2 jokers. For 3-4 player games, use 2 decks of cards with 4 jokers.

—description from the designer

Each player takes the role of a Caperucita Roja (Little Red Riding Hood) that must deliver three different items (flower, medicine, cake) to their grandma. In their turn, the players must roll a dice and then decide which path to take.
The winner is the player who arrives first to the grandma house with the three items.

In Vaca Muerta, the players take the role of energy companies which must decide where to invest. The workers are represented by dice and can be used to work in the field, build factories, convince the media, etc. Different generation systems (nuclear, hydroelectrical, coal, etc.) produce different amounts of money, corruption, and environmental damage.
The game includes a double point system, one for money and the other for corruption. At the end of the game, the player with the most corruption is out, and the winner is who has more money.

name.value: Choose Your Own Adventure: House of Danger

item.description:
The classic Choose Your Own Adventure series comes to life in the narrative adventure game Choose Your Own Adventure: House of Danger.

Will you survive the House of Danger? Gather your friends for a perilous and laughter-filled adventure through the House of Danger itself. Make risky choices, collect items as you explore, and face off against dire challenges. Play again and again to uncover more secrets and different endings!

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: Choose Your Own Adventure: House of Danger – Game Convention Promo Kit

item.description:
Story

Long time ago in the land of rising sun, spirits and demons known as Yokai were harming human lives.

Yokai did not directly attack people, but they were causing supernatural disasters: Yokai caused farmlands to burn, rivers to flood, thunders to roar, and diseases to spread.

One day a chieftain of the nearby village visited you, an Onmyoji, a practitioner of Japanese esoteric cosmology. Through your knowledge of astronomy and occultism, you discover the only way to help save the village. It is simple: the more Yokai you manage to capture, the less the menace caused by these demons. After a few months in the village, you are successful in your efforts; the Yokai menace is completely eradicated in that village!

Then, word reaches you of the havoc being wrecked by the Yokai on your own village. In your absence, the village chieftain has consulted another Onmyoji to help save your village. This is an affront because this is your village and the people under attack are your people. It is your job to save the day! Do not let another Onmyoji save the day and go down in history as the greatest there ever was and the Savior of your village at the time of need.

Compete against your rival Onmyoji and capture as many Yokai as you can!

				
					Gameplay Overview

In Yokai Septet, your goal is to capture high scoring Boss Yokai by strategically playing cards from your hand. Each turn, players play a card from their hand following the rules of the "trick taking games."

After everyone has played a card, the player who played the strongest card matching the lead suit takes all the cards played this turn. A new turn continues until one of the round's end condition is met. At the end of the round, the winner of that round is determined.

In a 4-player game, the game is played as a team battle of two players versus two players, whereas in a 3-player game, all players play individually competing. The winner of the round is the team that captured four or more Boss Yokai in a 4-player game, and three or more Boss Yokai in a 3-player game.

The winner of the round scores points based on the Boss Yokai they captured. New rounds are played until the game's end condition is met, which can be either 2 points for a basic game, or 7 points for an advanced game.

				
					Components


 49 cards (7 suits, 7 cards each)
 18 scoring tokens
 4 player aids
 1 lead player card

“But ‘twas a famous victory!”

Many wars have been fought to tip or maintain that illusive “balance of power” between nations, while including other objectives. The War of Spanish Succession might be the poster child for “balance” efforts, as demonstrated by the British… who allied with the Hapsburgs to stop a union between France and Spain…then left the war when it looked like the Hapsburgs could win (since Britain also feared a union of Spain and Austria!). Over the course of a 12-year war, there was much coming and going (along with secret negotiations and betrayals). The war included battlefields as far apart as Quebec and the Papal States, from the Netherlands to Hungary, and to various spots all over the German states. Including a small village on the Danube named Blindheim… which the British would garble as “Blenheim.”

Up to that point, things had been going well for the French and their armies looked to capture Vienna and take the Habsburgs out of the equation. Marlborough changed all that, but only after lying to his Dutch allies and virtually “stealing” the army he marched 250 miles away from the Low Countries he was expected to protect. After days of marching, countermarching, probes and parrying, the Allies attacked a foe of slightly larger size and in good positions, while the French were expecting them to retreat. Their cavalry was somewhat dispersed and too much of their infantry was in the towns of the area. And, up to that point, the French Army was considered “unbeatable.”

The battle went back and forth, with each side having opportunities for success but seeing confusion and heavy losses confound good plans. Certainly Marlborough and Eugene worked together marvelously well, especially for allies, which may have been the key difference. Tallard and Marsin and the Bavarians had their chances but missed them, needing infantry where they had cavalry and cavalry where they had infantry. When the British attacked the “seam” between the two forces, Marsin’s regiments fell back and Tallard’s collapsed. French losses were heavy, and their army’s aura of invincibility was gone forever.

The Battle of Blenheim from TPS focuses on the battlefield area itself, with each side having two distinct commands and forces. Players will command the varied forces of each side, with British, Dutch, Austrians, Prussians, Danes, and various German allies on one side and French, Bavarians, and even Irish fighting for Louis. Each unit in the game represents one brigade with each combat strength point around 400 men or 200 horses. One hex on the map equals 400 meters. A turn represents around one hour of action and the game can last up to 7 turns.

Though the war would continue for over 10 more years, Blenheim rates as “decisive” because this cost Louis the chance to knock the Habsburgs out of the war early. Instead, it would be his Bavarian allies who would lose out and become vassals to Vienna. In the end, the war would end as countries spun into exhaustion and a number of rulers died from age or sickness, making separate treaties that were finally consolidated under the Treat of Utrecht. France would not dominate the continent and, the most visible effect to us today, Britain still possesses Gibraltar.

—description from the publisher

/an-tin-uh-mee/ noun
(A contradiction between two beliefs or conclusions that are in themselves reasonable; a paradox)

As a Sorcerer, you have long sought ancient relics, imbued with magic. What unspeakable power can you unleash when you collect relics from anywhere in the spacetime continuum?

Antinomy is a head to head battle of wits as 2 competing sorcerers in search of powerful Paradox Crystals. Play a single card from your hand using the color or symbol to dive into the past, or use the number to fly into the future. The card you land on gets swapped with the card you played allowing you to build up a winning hand. Wherever you go, clever card play and a set of 3-of-a-kind cause paradoxes forming crystals of your own. Or confront your opponent in a Clash to wrest control of their crystals. Collecting 5 of these crystals will ensure your control over space and time. Do you have what it takes to wield the power of Antinomy?

-description from publisher

For hundreds of generations, the tyrannical Intercosmic Dynasty has ruled the galaxy with a titanium fist. Their power and reach is spreading, but so is word of their misdeeds. A band of resistance fighters known as the Liberation has begun striking at the Dynasty from a hidden base. Will you help the Liberation gain enough support before their secret base is discovered, or will the you wield the awesome power of the Dynasty to hunt down these traitors and bring them to heel?

Using a tiny deck of only 18 cards, Liberation plays out a miniature rebellion of galactic scale on your tabletop. An asymmetrical game of cat and mouse, the Dynasty player expands their web of power, occupying and exploiting planet cards, while the Liberation player strikes from the shadows, sabotaging the Dynasty’s hand and performing daring missions. The odds are long and the stakes are high. Can you stall long enough to cycle through the deck 3 times, earning enough support to topple the Dynasty, or will you scour the galactic map, tightening the noose around the secret base of the Liberation to attack and destroy them? The future of the galaxy is at stake!

Expansion and money, they go hand in hand. The great railways are expanding west which means there are fortunes to be made! Get ready to ride the rails as we wheel and deal shares of the Lincoln, Jefferson, and Roosevelt lines. If we play our cards right all the way from New York to St. Louis, we'll become rail barons overnight. Rest assured folks, this is the real McCoy!

In Penny Rails, players are stock holders in expanding rail lines reaching across the US.

Using only 18 cards and some loose change, you can relive the excitement of westward expansion right on your tabletop. Every turn you’ll get a chance to gain stocks or lay cards to build routes and increase your stock value! Each move counts as players vie for shares of the most profitable lines. When the first train pulls into the rail yard of St. Louis the player with the most profits wins. Will it be you?

If only...

Everyone has something about their past they desperately wish they could change: a terrible loss, that missed opportunity, the greatest of mistakes. If only you had known that that one tiny detail would make all the difference. If only you could do it again, everything would be different now. But if you WERE given the chance to rewrite history, would be brave enough to take it? Could you face the unknown and its unforeseen consequences? Could you fight fate to create the perfect moment?

In The Perfect Moment, players race to rewrite history in their favor using a deck of only 18 cards. Players use equipment, exploit paradoxes in the time-space continuum, and author their own revision of the past. Featuring a clever multi-sided card system, every card is used by both players based on what they can see. Equipping that card for yourself may just give your opponent the ability they were looking for. Every turn, players activate up to two revealed cards, which each have special effects. After the effects are resolved, the player can optionally score a card to earn up to 3 points depending on how closely they match it. The first player to 16 points wins. It takes careful planning and a bit of luck to avoid failing like you have so many times before. This time will be different.

This time...

link.value: The Perfect Moment: Las Vegas Gone Wrong

item.description:
Lords of Xibalba is a game where you take the role of one mischievous god of the underworld know as Xibalba and your goal is to increase your reputation by putting to test all the people that come by.

During the game you could allocate people in the different caves available in which you will send your messengers to apply the corresponding test, mess with others gods to avoid them to get a good reputation and above all avoid the people to escape.

Lords of Xibalba is a 2 to 4 players game where you're gonna test your abilities to strategize your movements and to use your hand to try to increase at maximum your reputation and become one of the legendary Lords in Mayan history.

—description from the publisher

You and your group are survivors of the zombie apocalypse. Your supplies are low. Tension is high. On your last supply raid, there was an attack...and it is possible one of you has been bitten...

You have five minutes to either gather enough supplies to leave your group...or you must discover and eliminate the player who has been bitten.

Bitten: Survive the Dead is a tense and exciting casual game for 2-8 Players with a 5-minute time limit. Players must attempt to gather one food ration, one water ration, one weapon, and the one available vehicle to leave the group, or they must discover which, if any, of the members of their group, have been bitten before time runs out and the bitten player becomes a member of the walking undead and eats your brains.

The original version was text only on cards in a tuck box. The second edition features all new artwork, modified rules including a few new cards, clay tokens for the items, and full illustrations on all the cards, the box, and the tokens.

-description from the designer

Board game Selfie Media "Zverometr" will give a lot of positive and excellent mood to your children. Applying their agility, logic and savvy, children will move towards victory. During the game you will have to measure yourself with longevity, speed and fluffiness of your animals. The winner of the game will be only one who turns out to be more dexterous and quick-witted.

On one side of the card - the name and picture with the beast, on the other - the figures for the four properties:

The size,
Longevity,
Travel speeds,
Fuzzy.
To each property are added points, proportional to the values.

Each player in his turn receives 4 cards, but does not look at the reverse side with the data. He needs to arrange these animals in order of increasing points for a single property. When the cards are arranged in a row, the player turns them over. If the sequence is correct, he gets one card for himself in the bank, if not - he puts all the cards back into the deck. Each player has three such moves, then everyone counts the earned points.

The hill hides many treasures, and all it takes to collect them is to grab your shovel and dig!

Well, maybe not as these aren't the only things the hill hides; creatures and traps await, so the tunnels that you create might lead to either wealth or despair. Delve into the hill and gather ten gems to win the game! Take some risks, press your luck, hire recruits to dig deeper and win favors of companions such as the knight, wizard, scout or hunter to protect your collections from the many creatures — thieves, skeletons, orcs, and more — and traps hidden in the hill.

DIG finds its path between adventure, strategy, luck, and resource management. In this card-driven game for 2 to 4 players ages 10 and up, fun meets strategy, luck meets role-playing and fantasy meets pixel art design within 20 to 45 minutes.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
In Stalin Assassin, each player is randomly assigned a role.

4 possible roles at the start: Stalin, Commis, Capitalists and The Bolshevik. The Capitalists always have a majority, the Commis know who they are the Capitalists and Commis do not know who is Stalin or The Bolshevik.

Stalin and The Bolshevik are always in incognito and also do not know who they are.

5 to 11 players:

5 players - 2 Capitalists, 1 Commi, 1 Stalin and 1 Bolshevik

6 and 7 players - 3 or 4 Capitalists, 1 Commi, 1 Stalin and 1 Bolshevik

8 to 11 players - 3 Commi, 1 Stalin, 1 Bolshevik and all other Capitalists

HAMMER OF POWER passes from a player to the other and all players have to put their thumbs up or down to accept the HAMMER of POWER (POWER TOOL OR PT) given to the player selected. If the player gets most okays he picks 2 cards and places his chosen one on the board.

There is 1 board where actions are taken. 11 action in total. 1

Each time the HAMMER OF POWER is passed to a player. That player takes 2 TOOL Cards and places 1 on the BOARD (COMMI POWER TOOL or FREEDOM CARD). Then he places the one not chosen back in the pile of cards *at the bottom).

If at action 3 and 4 there is a COMMI POWER TOOL - TIME FOR WILD GUESS - where all will guess who is a Commi The "appointed" Commi gets an UNDERCOVER COMMI card and is suspected to be a Commi.

The board is called Mother Russia.

—description from the publisher

Comitatus is a complete set of wargames rules designed to simulate warfare in Europe and the Mediterranean from about AD 250 to 1100. They have been primarily designed with Barbarian Migrations period in mind but the scope of the rules covers Dark Age warfare through to the period of the First Crusade.

Comitatus is a fast moving game that is relatively easy to master. Full-scale battles representing tens of thousands of troops on each side can easily be fought to a conclusion in 3-4 hours while still retaining the special characteristics of dark age warfare.

Civitates Bellantes is a set of miniatures wargame rules for battles in the Hellenistic and early-mid Imperial Roman periods. The rules are derived from the same designer's Late Antique / Early Medieval set Comitatus.

Legio VI Julia Augusta is a set of miniatures wargames rules aimed to allow large battles of Roman Late Republican and Early Imperial periods (100 BC to AD 250) to be resolved relatively quickly. It's meant for 6mm figures but could easily be adapted to larger (or smaller!) figures.

The rules are derived from the same designer's Comitatus set of Dark Ages rules, but slimmed down to allow larger battles to be fought in less time. Troops are classed a relatively small number of troop types with minimal differentiation based on equipment; the focus is on troop quality and, especially, generals' limited means of controlling their forces.

The rules are freely available from the designer's webpage, along with sister sets covering adjoining periods:

Legio VI Macedonia, for 400 BC to 100 BC
Legio VI Constantiniani, for AD 250 to AD 600
Legio VI Diadochi, for Alexander and the Successors

Braintopia Beyond is the follow-up to the fast-paced brain bender that tests your mental focus, flexibility, and speed. Comprised of eight different types of challenges, up to six players race through a deck of cards, fighting to keep up with the ever-changing mini-games, and attempt to solve the puzzles faster than their opponents. Collect brain tokens by beating a single Touch challenge or claiming a pair of cards from any of the other seven games: Multitasking, Observation, Squares, Analysis, Unique, Combination, and Tracking. The first player to collect four brain tokens wins!

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Braintopia Kids is a follow-up to the fast-paced brain bender that tests your mental focus, flexibility, and speed, but geared toward younger players. Comprised of eight different types of challenges, up to six players race through a deck of cards, fighting to keep up with the ever- changing mini-games, and attempt to solve the puzzles faster than their opponents. Collect brain tokens by beating a single Touch challenge or claiming a pair of cards from any of the other seven games: Maze, Odd one out, Coordination, Duplicates, Frequency, and Reasoning. The first player to collect four brain tokens wins!

—description from the publisher

Garden in Time and Space is a real time co-operative roll and write PNP game. Players need to irrigate all their flowers in very limited time.
But please notice, there will be portals appear in your garden and disturb your plan.
In the game, simultaneously, players repeatly roll their dice to determint which type of waterpipe they can draw on their own board.They have to connect pipe to other exist pipe.But if they roll a portal then connect it to a pipe, one of other players will have to draw a portal in same coordinate on his board.Now pipe will grow out from the portal, which may disturb his original drawing plan or may help him connect pipe to their flowers more easily.
The object of game is to irrigate all players' flowers in 3 minutes. Otherwise, all players lose.

—description from the publisher

Shieldwall aims to recreate the atmosphere of Dark Age battles in the British Isles and Northern Europe. The rules were inspired by Andy Callan's Dark Age Infantry Slog. They adapt the basic Comitatus mechanisms to provide interest and colour to what otherwise might be a fairly boring game of two more or less identically armed shieldwalls crashing into each other.

If you like Vikings and Saxons this could be the game for you!

Miniatures battle game for the 1700-1720 period in Europe (so principally the War of the Spanish Succession and the Great Northern War). The rules are based on those for Andy Callan's Loose Files and American Scramble, a AWI set.

The game aims to capture the transitional nature of early 18C warfare, one foot in the "pike & shot" era, one in the "horse and musket" period. Individual battalions and squadrons are represented, but the practical units of manoeuvre are brigades or even groups of brigades, allowing large battles to be fought in a timely manner.

These rules are designed for re-creating small scale skirmishes with miniature figures. Although designed primarily for conflict in North America in the 17th -19th centuries, they can be used to re-create actions in various times and places.

Scale:
These rules can be used with figures ranging from 15mm to 54mm. Each model figure represents between one and five men. Time and distance scales have been deliberately distorted in the interests of practicality and playability.

All measurements are given in multiples of ‘10 paces’. Ten paces is 3cm if using 25/28 mm figures. Adjust up or down for larger or smaller figures

These rules are available as a free download on the publisher's website

In ãƒ™ãƒ«ãƒ¼ã‚¬ (Beluga), you play as a mother beluga whale whose echo location system isn't working properly, which is a problem as your daughter is lost and you want to reunite with her.

The game is divided into two halves: "Journey" and "Reunion". In "Journey", players collect ice cards that contain clues to the daughter's location while trying not to be found by their natural enemy, the polar bear. The closer you get to a polar bear, the most cards you have and the more of your daughter's clues are available, but should you accidentally find the polar bear, you will be eaten.

In "Reunion", you try to find your daughter by revealing the ice cards that you collected in the first half of the game. Once again, you must avoid polar bears. Thankfully you can reference magpies in the sky that know the location of these bears, while also reaching out to "old sharks" to find shortcuts to your daughter's location.

Can mom find her courage and reunite with her daughter?

link.value: ひとりじゃ、生きられない。(I Cannot Live By Myself)

item.description:
Efemeris is a fabulous adventure that carries you away to explore the firmament aboard French, English and Spanish navy vessels. Maneuver through the skies using stellar winds, to be the first Nation to dominate the trade routes by opening the safest courses to your territories.

Efemeris has 2 game modes: a highly competitive duel mode and cooperative team mode.

Play as a fleet commander and use strategy to conquer 5 planets that will ensure the hegemony of your Nation.
Choose your captains for their unique skill, and watch over the recruitment of their crew.
Explore the canopy of heavens and collect the resources needed for your business.
Destroy mercilessly enemy vessels that dare to confront your fleet.

—description from the publisher

It's the fun, fast-paced card game you love now featuring iconic characters from the thrilling WWE! Players race to get rid of all their cards by matching a card in their hand with the current card shown on top of the deck. When you throw down the powerful Locked Up card, you choose another player with whom you'll lock into battle. Only one will survive! Other action cards include Skips, Reverses, Draw Twos, and Wild Cards-including a customizable Wild Card. The first player or team to 500 wins, and when you're down to one card, don't forget to yell "UNO!"

—description from the publisher

Welcome, jagger, to the Grid. The Grid is an isolated network specifically designed to test illicit hacking software. You will scan the Grid for data sources, which you will use to power your programs. Battle other jaggers to see who has the best programs. Win, and know that your software is good enough to take on corporate networks. Lose, and rebuild your software suite to try again.

Jagger Arena is a dueling card game for 2-4 players. Players are 'jaggers', criminal hackers that us AI programs to break into corporate networks. Jaggers come to the Grid to test their programs against each other; battling until only one jagger is left standing.

Before a match, you will chose a program set of 7 cards to use in the battle. The game comes with four pre-built program sets, but you can also mix the different programs to create your own custom set.

On your turn, you will reveal a face down card in the Grid of 25 cards. Your goal is to make a match of 3 or more of the same data source symbol. These data source matches are used to trigger attacks from your programs, or use a program's special abilities. Certain cards can generate chains, allowing you to reveal multiple cards in a turn. And watch out for logic bombs! Logic bombs can reveal a large number of cards, giving you an opportunity to make multiple matches. Your program abilities can alter the Grid, and cause various effects that hinder your opponent's programs.

Using program attacks and abilities, you will attempt to delete your opponent's programs. If all your programs are deleted, you are eliminated from the match. The last player left is declared the winner.

Future expansion packs will include new program sets and abilities, allowing for more variety when creating custom program sets. The introduction of new logic bombs will cause more chaos in the Grid.

Contents:
62 Data Source cards
28 Program cards (Alice, Boris, Cameron, and Logan program sets)
9 Logic Bomb cards
24 Damage tokens
16 Strengthen/Weaken tokens
16 Infect tokens
6 Data Source tokens

-description from designer

name.value: Micro Miners: A Micro Deck Builder

item.description:
Micro Miners: A micro deck builder takes a full size deck building experience and compacts it down to the size of about a standard deck of cards. The game shifts the focus from collecting many cards to collecting the right cards at the right time for deck optimization. Every time you shuffle your deck you will bring your deck size down to the your current limit keep your deck dedicated to the actions you care about. Players need to choose the cards they take from the Tunnel carefully if they want to load the final gem into a cart and score a point.

Micro Miners is played like many deck builders and can be played by taking turns gaining cards and using them to score points. However in Micro Miners each player starts their turn with 3 Effort which allows them to take actions. They can spend a number of effort indicated to acquire an available card from the tunnel or use it to play a Cart in front of them. It can also be used to load gems into any suitable cart in play controlled by any player, but any player can block the gem from being loaded if they have a gem that matches the targeted cart.

Players have a hand limit size of just 2 cards and will draw a new hand at the the end of each turn. If they ever need to draw cards but their draw pile does not have enough they will shuffle their discard pile to form a new draw deck. Each time they do this they will count the number of cards in their deck, not including any carts in play or gems loaded into them, and will choose which cards to discard down to their deck limit. All discarded cards will be Tossed face down into the Shaft.

The first player to score 3 points will win this micro deckbuilder.

Plays in 20-30 minutes.

Players take the role of Bariesus, powerful mages capable of manipulating the four elements. Players must conquer territories through combat, driven by cards. The mages can summon armies of air, earth, water, and fire, as well as different spells, and the combat is ultimately defined by the played cards.
Conquered territories give taxes, and the money is needed to hire mercenaries.
The game is over when a player conquers a given number of territories or, if nobody has won in 20 turns, the God Kasdail destroys the universe.

In this real-time game, the players must simultaneously and continuously play cards on its own boards trying to defeat at least one of the different powers of any of the opponent's cards and take them. The effects of the played cards are instantaneous and change the powers and abilities of other cards in play.

The game is played in rounds until the deck is empty (more players means less time). When this happens, the players count the total strength of the defeated cards, and who has more is declared the winner.

It can also be played in constructed deck mode.

You’ve awaken as a cube in a world with domino tiles falling from the sky, being chased by this ominous black cube for reasons unknown. All you can do is run. For some reason you know that the black cube must never catch you. You also know that, when you complete double value domino tiles you gain power-ups that help you run better. Suddenly a vision, “Get all seven keys to escape…”

A solo roll & move print and play adventure game.

The uses domino tiles to create an infinite track. The player rolls their dice pool to move their white cube through the pip requirements of the domino track. Complete key double domino tiles to gain new dice or draw domino tiles powers that can upgrade matching dice values. Don't let the enemy black cube get to you though as it may just cause you to loose the game. Complete all 7 keys to win!

name.value: Star Wars: Han Solo Card Game

item.description:
The Han Solo Card Game is inspired by a legendary card game from the Star Wars universe! In this exciting game, players try to score as close to zero as they can with their cards. They can add or swap cards to improve their hand during each round, but rolling the dice and getting doubles will shake things up. At the end of a hand, the best score collects the most valuable bounty token. If you collect wisely, you can even steal the Millennium Falcon – the highest valued token. The player whose tokens add up to the highest value at the end of the game wins.

Contents includes: 62 cards, 24 cardboard bounty tokens, 2 dice, and instructions.
-description from publisher's website

The Star Wars: Han Solo Card Game is a hand-management game where players take turns drawing and discarding cards one at a time in hopes of ending the round with the sum of their card values closest to zero. The winner of each round gets first pick of a rotating selection of bounty tokens, and the player with the most valuable bounty tokens at the end of the game wins.
-user summary

In Too Many Heroes, players take on the role of rival corporations, racing to be the first to build their super-team of heroes. But you’re not building a team to fight crime and injustice...you’re in it for the money. Movie rights, book deals, sponsorships...you name it!

It’s a fast paced card game for 2-6 players. The massive deck contains 216 cards, featuring 100 fully-realized heroes. Fighting alongside them are villains, action cards, upgrades, downgrades, and the coveted License Cards. Yes, License cards. Your heroes must be licensed to count. Otherwise they’re classified as illegals, operating under the law, vigilantes, and most importantly for the government, untaxable.

—description from the publisher

Z-Game 2 is a competitive strategy game for 2-4 players who accumulate resources, recruit mercenaries, destroy the last strongholds of civilization, fulfill missions and fight with zombies.

Try to survive in post-apocalyptic world! On their turn, the player moves around the city tiles, destroy them, enters into battles with other players and zombies by playing cards from the hand - all in order to fulfill the current goal of the round.

At the beginning of each round, a new event card is opened. If this is the 8th card, you will play the final round.
Then update the goals of the round. In each round, goals are different, so players will always have something to do.
After this setup of the round, players perform their turns which include three phases: 1. moving, 2. fighting, if they meet with enemies, and 3. getting resources from occupied territories and feeding crew.

The game also ends if one player has completed eight or more goals.

The winner is the player who accomplished most of the goals. If there is a tie here, then the winner is the one who has more people left in the city. If there is a tie here, arrange an arm wrestling - in the post-apocalypse there is always only one winner!

The game boasts simple rules, dynamic mechanics, large number of components, unique art, and exciting scenarios! Win in a world of senseless cruelty and causeless violence, crowded with hordes of zombies and crazy gangs in the board game about the zombie apocalypse Z-Game!

Dale of Merchants Collection is a standalone game. It contains plenty of content aimed at fans of the series. The game comes with a large box which lets you store all content both from the original Dale of Merchants and Dale of Merchants 2.

While this is a great storage solution to keep all your Dale of Merchants content in a single box, it does come with a ton of new things to play with. Dale of Merchants Collection introduces new animalfolk decks with such unique fellows as Wealthy Tuataras and Connected Emperor Penguins.

A completely new feature in the series are the character cards. These cards are received at the start of the game and provide players with unique and powerful abilities that drastically influence the game. Dale of Merchants Collection includes dozens of different character cards adding even more depth and variance to the series' gameplay.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Jake and the Neverland Pirates Speed Match Game

item.description: Players take turns rolling dice to reveal the combination of image (a character from Jake and the Neverland Pirates), background color and perimeter color that all players will search for among 54 revealed combinations on the modular board. The player that finds the correct combination places her token on that combination on the board. The first player to place all of their tokens on the board wins the game.

name.value: The G.O.O.D Game: Get Out Of Dodge

item.description:
After the economic collapse, use your survivalist gear to get through obstacles on a trek from your office to your bug out location.

Everyone begins with 7 Gear cards and a dice roll determines who goes first. On each round, roll the dice to advance your player piece on the game board. Follow your Determiner card and the instructions on the space where you land, as luck decides whether you gain or lose gear (cards) or fall prey to other dangers. If two players land on the same space, you can barter your gear or form alliances. The winner is the first player to make it to the bug out cabin.

Contains politically incorrect material and some harsh language.

ç¥žä¹(Kami nine) is a game that gives offerings to traditional Japanese Kami(gods) and benefits(score).

Each player gives offerings to the three gods in play, only God who gained the most will give a score.

The player who gained the most benefit (score) wins.

The number of players is 3 to 5 people, we recommend playing with 4 people.

Board game about milk-producing.

in his turn player rolls die and moves around the board.
After each turn he draws one card with same color what is the space he landed. Each time if somebody has moved all round he may exchange the cards with other players. Players may not show the color-side of the cards to each other.
If any player has collected all 9 cards in one and the same color during the game he is the winner.

'With the birth of the Kirs, shape, space, and time have been moved. The universe was determined by "Kir of Run" — the direction of movement — and the gods settled in their Tums on the edges of the world.

Slavic mythology is a little-known theme for games, one that can hide many secrets. Å»ercy is both a card game and a first attempt to create a complete representation of the Slavic gods and disclose this mythology full of mysteries.

Who are the Å»ercy? They are priests of ancient gods who attempt to manipulate reality in subtle ways. They are mercenaries in the hands of tribal chieftains, who attempt to divine success or disaster in coming wars. Å»ercy, by making proper sacrifices, want to obtain a favor of Kir, the one they serve, while striving at the same time to change the natural balance of power.

In the game, each player impersonates a Å»erca, a priest of one of four Kirs, gods who represent both the seasons and the directions of the world:

 Jaruna (spring, east)
 Rujewit (summer, south)
 Jesz (autumn, west)
 Kostroma (winter, north)




You must read signs in the continuous changes around you. Choose a direction for your actions and for the Kir that you want to serve. All gods who appear in the game belong to one of four Tums created by Kirs; the inspiration for the graphic representation of the gods comes from images of nature, in which the attentive observer can notice much more than just a chaos of random configurations.

name.value: One-Minute Washita River: Custer faces defeat and disaster in 1868

item.description:
The game can be crudely described as Monopoly meets Scrabble. The premise is based on property development, but tile placement and scoring is similar to Scrabble.

Each player has a hand of tiles, set up on a tile stand. Each player in turn has the opportunity of placing tiles on the board alongside and tiles already on the board. Each tile placed on the board automatically makes a row (or "street") longer. At the very least a new street consisting of two tiles is formed when a new tile is laid.

Whenever a player so manages to lengthen a street by placing a new tile on the board, he scores the new total arithmetical value of the street, for as far as it extends in a straight unbroken line. Each successive tile added on to a given street will score more and more as the street increases in length and value.

Tiles must be matched to the board by color and number as a general rule, but there are a number of "joker" tiles that do not conform to this.

The game ends when the first player achieves 1000 (2 player), 800 (3 player) or 650 points (4 player).

Players are divided into two teams. Each team must take a situation, character, and challenge cards. Then, they must invent a history based on those elements and finally act them.
The winner will be the team that had accomplished the largest number of situations.

This is a Kirby board game where players are creating sweets by collecting different ingredients.

Exerpts from the box (rough translation from Japanese):
Today I called Kirby's friends and had a sweet party! I am busy preparing for it now. Let's make a lot of sweets while sometimse helping your friends!

This game is a game where players compete for points as a fine patissier. The game is divided into two parts, Sweets Making and Sweets Party.

In Sweets Making, you get points by arranging materials that are on sweets cards and completing them. You can also earn points by raising money and helping other players.

Sweets Party is where you invite guests and get points if you have a favoriet sweet of the invited guest.

Subtitled "Mit Spaß und Fantasie durchs Moor", this is a game published as part of the Expo 2000 campaign "Das Tote Moor soll leben" ("The Dead Moor Is To Live Again") to promote restoration of the Dead Moor area near Hannover, a historic peat stripping site. In addition to the rules of the game, the rulebook contains information on the biotopes, wildlife, history, archaeology and folklore of the moor, although the game itself is not of an overtly educational nature. Max Moorfrosch, the project mascot, also makes an appearance as a joker tile in the game.

The game is set in medieval times and is played on a board of hexagonal spaces representing the moor. Village tiles are placed on the perimeter, and a peat-mining tile is placed in the middle. By placing log road tiles, players race to connect their two villages with a causeway passing through the peat-mining site, and the first player or team to complete this connection wins the game.

Before each turn, a card is turned over to reveal the advice of the village elders, which may involve missing a turn due to bad weather, being restricted to playing a certain type of tile that turn due to a mishap, getting a double placement due to good weather, or some such. Obstacle tiles are also encountered on the board face down, and mostly have to simply be built around, although some when approached and turned up may also offer an opportunity to place a bridge directly across, or require expenditure of special resources (like an offering for the sacrificial site and using torch-lit roads to keep away the ghosts), or even provide the magical power of the Golden Helm to ward off hazards.

The game contains rules for one, two or four players; in the latter case, two players make up a team with partially shared resources, each joining up their village with the peat tile instead of working from one village to the other. There are also suggestions for any number of players to cooperate as one team or compete as two.

This electric game is based on Walt Disney's Disneyland theme park in Anaheim, California and weekly television show of the same name.

A playing board sheet is laid over the base and the players move along the trail. The base has a circuit selector, wire connector with a metal tip that is touched to spots on the board and red light that allows or hinders the player's progress; underneath the base is a place for a battery to be installed to power the light.

Each game has a trail going over the points of interest and the player reaching the goal first wins the game.

After the traveler and opponent are decided, the traveler spins the spinner to determine how many steps to travel along the trail. The traveler determines whether to continue his trip by placing the contact tip on the station. If the light signal goes on, he continues traveling, otherwise he places his Disney character on the station as a marker and remains there and waits for his next turn

The opponent can confuse and obstruct the traveler by operating the rotary switch occasionally, to change the circuit so that the signal light will not light up and delay the traveler's progress.

If a traveler is not careful and picks the trail up wrong and heads back towards the starting point, he loses all previous plays and starts his travel all over again. The winner of the game is the first traveler reaching the goal

Game consists of 4 playing boards in full color (Fantasyland, Tomorrowland, Frontierland, & Adventureland), 4 character players, spinner, electric circuit complete with flashlight-type battery (Requires 1 D battery for the light).

Produced sometime in the 1950s

Help your Favorite Walt Disney characters board the Casey Jr Express.

Spin the three arrow spinner and choose only one of the three moves indicated:

Take any car (as indicated by the short arrow).
Take any ticket (as indicated by the long arrow) however you can't do this unless you have an empty car.
Take any rider (as indicated by the medium arrow) however you can't do this until you have the proper car to put him in and you must return a ticket for ever rider you put in a proper car.

Place the cars and riders as you get them in their corresponding slots on the track in front of you.

The first player to get all of his characters aboard is the winner

Set in the Middle Ages, Chivalry is a family game in which you can play as a knight apprentice who strives to get a higher rank and honor his family. By visiting every corner around the kingdom, you will gather knight spirits to enhance yourself and make yourself well-prepared for future challenges. In the end, the player with the most knight virtue will be the knight exemplar and bathe in the praise and applause of the crowds.

Briefly speaking, there are three actions players take in Chivalry: Rest, Patrol, and Promote. Rest is the phase for knights to stay and prepare their equipment and supplies, while Patrol is the phase to gather everything you need in the kingdom, or go to castle to get reward from the King. The most important phase is Promote, which symbolized your conquering of the trials and earn yourself knight virtues to elevate in the knight rank. Whenever a knight being promoted, there will be extra bonus for him to manifest the nobility. The game ends when any player collects the designated number of knight virtues, and the one with most virtues wins this game.

In the 17th Century, the capital of the Dutch East Indies was Batavia (now Jakarta in Indonesia). Many Dutch merchants wanted to get wealthy trading spices and crops. Nobility desire cardamon; cloves were sought for medicine; cinnamon for its deep, sweet fragrance; and ginger and pepper for their strong spicy flavors. Buy spices, send them to Europe, get rich, and succeed as big merchants!

From Batavia (ãƒ•ãƒ­ãƒ ï¼šãƒã‚¿ãƒ´ã‚£ã‚¢) is a card-drafting game of sorts. In general, each player has a ship, and they'll place cargo cards on the ship until it's full, after which they get a new ship. Whoever fills three ships first wins!

In more detail, each ship card has a hold number and possibly an icon. The cargo cards come in five types (cardamon, cloves, cinnamon, ginger, pepper), and they have a cost, an effect, an icon, and a money value. Grain cards have nothing but a picture of grain, yet they can be valuable, too. Each player starts with a hand of five cargo cards.

On a turn, each player chooses a cargo card from their hand, then they reveal them simultaneously. If they can afford to pay the cost of their card, they do so, discarding cards from hand equal to the cost (with a card of the same color as the revealed cargo card counting for two cards) and handing those cards to their -left-hand neighbor. All cards are passed at the same time. If a player can't pay the cost of their card, they return it to hand, then give their left-hand neighbor one cargo card from the top of the deck.

All players who paid the cost of their new cargo card now carry out the effect of that card. Ginger, for example, lets you draw grain cards equal to the number of ginger icons on your cargo cards and ship card; grain cards can't be placed on ships, but they can be used to pay for cargo. Cinnamon lets you take a coin and place it on your ship, then discard as many cards as you want to take additional coins; each coin helps to fill the hold of your ship.

If the money value of a player's cargo cards (along with any coins they have) equal or exceed the hold value of a ship, that ship is full. The player places that ship aside, discards the cargo cards, then takes a new ship in a different color.

Each player can discard any number of cards from their hand, then each person with fewer than six cards draws one cargo card from the deck. Cardamon icons can let you draw a card even if you have six or more cards, while cloves lets you draw additional cards anytime you draw cargo, then discard the same number of cards that you drew additionally. Filter cards to find what you want!

Perception of time is a difficult skill that takes many months to fully develop in children.


 What is a half-hour?
 Is five minutes a lot?
 Why is the hour split into 60 minutes?


All of these questions require understanding and the habit of correlating clock-hand movements with flow of day and night. The new game from The Brainy Band will help children to determine the time on the clock-face, to figure out the relation between “hours” and “minutes,” and to learn the notions of time and duration of activities.

By performing different fun tasks, the players will move around the game board designed in the form of a clock-face. The players’ objective is to do as much as possible in the course of the game, while preventing others from completing their activities and moving forward.

—description from the publisher

The goal is to be the first to win 20 hazelnuts.
One can win hazelnuts by mimicking correctly and the right orders the gestures of Billy the hamster and Jean-Claude the worm on cards.

One after the other, the players draw cards that they place in front of them. They can stop drawing cards whenever they want (with a minimum of one card). When they think they have enough cards, they stop and say "Bandit servi !" ("The bandit is served!"). Then they have one second per card to memorize the gestures and the order of the cards. At the end of that time, the player closes their eyes and must mimic the gestures correctly and in the right order. If the player is correct, they win the amount of nuts on the cards, if not, they don't win or lose anything.

There are three types of special cards:
- double ration: if the player is correct, they win double the amount of nuts;
- double temps (double time): the player has two seconds per card to memorize the gestures;
- haut les pattes ! (paws up!): every player must rise their hands and say "paws up!", the first one wins one nut from the bank.

Components:
- 48 cards (including 8 special cards)
- 35 nut tokens: 20x 1 nut tokens, 10x 5 nuts tokens, 5x 10 nuts tokens

In Respuestas Abiertas (Open answers), players must move on the board and taking cards of two different types:
- Cards with text, in which the player must answer personal and hilarious questions, and the other players try to guess the answer.
- Cads with images, in which the player must invent a phrase or words about it.
Correct guesses give points, and the winner is who has more points at the end of the game.

Ladronia is a fun and dynamic board game. Five adventurers must enter the dark lord's dungeon in search of treasures. But this will be full of enemies, traps, obstacles and dangerous events. Each player must advance and explore through the dungeon, even steal their own companions to obtain the immense treasure.

Game components:
- 1 board
- 135 cards
- 1 rules
- 11 dices (1 black, 5 red and 5 blue)
- 5 colored chips
- 1 box

The turn of each player:
- Move: each player in turn must advance through the board to reach the treasure room.
- Explore or steal: the player can explore the zones to find treasures and useful objects or steal cards from other players.
- Playing cards: the player can play cards from his hand (skills, objects, actions ...).

The objective of the game is to accumulate the maximum of treasure cards (steal, explore or get to the treasure room). The game ends in three ways:
1. When a player arrives at the treasure room.
2. When there are no more treasures.
3. When there are no more events.
The player with the most treasures wins the game.

-description from designer



Ladronia es un divertido y dinámico juego de mesa. Cinco aventureros deberán adentrarse en la mazmorra del señor oscuro en busca de tesoros. Pero esta se encontrará repleta de enemigos, trampas, obstáculos y sucesos peligrosos. Cada jugador deberá avanzar y explorar por la mazmorra llegando incluso a robar a los propios compañeros con tal de conseguir el inmenso tesoro".

Componentes del juego:
- 1 tablero
- 135 cartas
- 1 reglas
- 11 dados (1 negro, 5 rojo y 5 azul)
- 5 fichas de colores
- 1 caja

El turno de cada jugador:
- Avanzar: cada jugador a su vez debe avanzar a través del tablero para llegar a la sala del tesoro.
- Explorar o robar: el jugador puede explorar las zonas para encontrar tesoros y objetos útiles o robar cartas de otros jugadores.
- Jugar cartas: el jugador puede jugar cartas de su mano (habilidades, objetos, acciones ...).

El objetivo del juego es acumular el máximo de cartas del tesoro (robar, explorar o llegar a la sala del tesoro). El juego termina de tres maneras:
1. Cuando un jugador llega a la sala del tesoro.
2. Cuando no hay más tesoros.
3. Cuando no hay más eventos.
El jugador con más tesoros gana el juego.

Professor Ravenwood's Time Machine is a semi co-op mystery/investigation game for 2-6 players. It features elements of hand/resource management, take-that, variable player powers plus randomization which ensures it cannot be played the same way twice.

Players must work by shipping goods and trading with each other to earn enough money to buy the supplies they need to reach each location.

Once a player has the necessary supplies and holds one of the 28 map locations, they can move to the investigate phase.

Each location is always a mystery. There could be someone in hiding, holding a set of blueprints, or a shady character you will have to deal with. It may also contain a mystery crate with unknown contents..

Mystery crates however are padlocked, and can only be opened with a skeleton key. They may contain missing components of the Time Machine or unusual artifacts which will convey positive or negative effects onto the player, or everyone else.

At one of the locations, Professor Ravenwood has been locked away. When he is found, the identity of the mole can be revealed, which is one of the players chosen secretly at random at the beginning of the game.

With their cover blown, that player now becomes a Saboteur, receiving a unique deck of instruction cards, and whose mission is to subvert the search and recover as many of the missing blueprints and components before the others.

Players share the win or loss against the Saboteur, however each is also out for their share of the reward, so the person who contributes the most to the search will gain the victory points and be declared the winner.

If the Saboteur wins, all is lost. Professor Ravenwood's Time Machine must not be allowed to fall into the wrong hands.

-description from designer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Educational twist on dominoes, issued in the DDR.
Each Domino has a sum on it. In order to add to the line you must have a domino that features the correct answer to that sum. The box lid gives a good example of the game
First to get rid of all their dominoes wins.

Face off in a chaotic version of Chess in a Fan Game inspired by the Code Geass anime.

Play as either Lelouch or Schneizel during the Chinese Federation Arc and out wit your opponents by bending the rules of Chess to your advantage with unique cards and abilities.

Using the game's two decks of cards, as well as a regular chess set, player play the standard game of chess with 1 exception:

Each turn, a player draws back up to 4 cards from their unique Lelouch or Schneizel deck. Then, a player plays up to a single card from their hand, before moving their piece for the turn.

—description from the designer

Download the Print and Play here: https://www.brotherminggames.com/
Play the Table Top Simulator here: https://steamcommunity.com/workshop/filedetails/?id=1367936675

Join the Eurovision Song Contest with your own entry and try to score as many points as possible in the Eurovision Song Contest board game! Test your knowledge, prepare your own performance, and participate in the most popular song contest! Will you get those 12 points first?

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: In ãµãã‚ã¨é‡‘è²¨ (Moneybags), players try to have the most gold coins, with each player having their own bag filled with some number of brass coins. If you think you have the most coins, you might want to exit the round to keep them as others will try to transfer coins from your bag to theirs!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Bee Lives: We Will Only Know Summer

item.description:
Bee Lives: We Will Only Know Summer is a game designed to run 1-4 players through a year of managing a wild bee hive. Players of this medium-weight Eurogame utilize resource management and worker placement mechanisms to be the hive that sets up the best possible path for its survival.

In more detail, in Bee Lives you manage your own hive by interacting with both your internal hive player board and the shared external board that is made up of tiles and collaboratively built by all of the players. During the game, you swarm to propagate your bees and score victory points, but these newly formed wild hives compete with you and the other players for resources on the board. Can you ensure your hive will make it through winter?

Experience the no holds barred world of power politics as you wheel and deal your way to the top. Scandal, blackmail, crisis and leadership contests. These and other political pitfalls and opportunities are encountered as the game develops to challenge players wit and skill.

Play the political cards you acquire. Run with your luck to race through the board to No 10. Alternatively lay in wait and use your cards to defeat opponents before stealing to No 10 - if you can. The choice of strategy is yours when you play this exciting game of political ambition and intrigue.

From the back of the box

MystiQuest tells of epic clashes between ancient gods, fought on the banks of the Styx, the infernal river. Gods, heroes, monsters and mythological creatures battle with all their power, fighting during the day and spending the night celebrating.

Is a trading card game, but very close to the Living Card Games, thanks to the use of Planks, tokens and the possibility to implement long-term strategies.

Each player has a board representing the fortress, on which he places the card of his Supreme Nume (or Prime) and the three heralds chosen to defend it. The heralds also represent Defence Points: if they are eliminated or used, the Prime is forced to take the field and expose himself in person. The winner first eliminates the Prime opponent.

It is interesting to note that the heralds can be chosen before starting the game and this allows you to plan very specific and different strategies according to the opponent you will have to face.

Mystic energy is represented by plastic gems. After playing a card you must take the gems from your well and place them on it. The gems on the card indicate the attack value, the defense value and the card’s hit points. As a result, a card with three gems, deals three damage and can take three damage before it dies out, if it takes a damage it loses a gem and then inflicts only two damage from that moment.

During the confrontation phase the player on duty plays his own cards, sends them to the attack and uses his own prodigies to try to defeat the enemy ranks and force the Prime opponent to take the field.

At the end of the turn there is the breath phase. Temples, Prime and some other specific cards "breathe" and give mystical energy back to their well, so you can add new gems. Then it is up to the opponent to repeat the same sequence until one of the two Prime is defeated.

Another interesting feature is the possibility of playing in teams, even with "asymmetric" solutions: one against two, two against three, two against four, etc. thanks to the gaming system that automatically self-balances.

For the setting the mythological theme was chosen as an alternative to the now too widespread Fantasy. Currently it is possible to play with three Pantheon:
- Ancient Greeks
- Ancient Egyptians
- Vikings
The Japanese pantheon is already being prepared.



MystiQuest racconta di epici scontri fra antiche divinità, combattuti sulle rive dello Stige, il fiume infernale. Dei, eroi, mostri e creature mitologiche si danno battaglia con tutta la loro potenza, combattendo di giorno e passando la notte a festeggiare.E’ un gioco di carte collezionabili, ma molto vicino ai Living Card Games grazie all’utilizzo di Plance, gettoni e la possibilità di attuare strategie a lungo termine.
 Ogni giocatore ha una plancia che rappresenta la fortezza, su cui posiziona la carta del proprio Nume Supremo (o Prime) e i tre araldi scelti per difenderlo. Gli araldi rappresentano anche Punti Ferita del Prime, infatti se vengono eliminati o utilizzati, il Prime è costretto a scendere in campo ed esporsi in prima persona. Vince chi per primo elimina il Prime avversario.

E’ interessante notare che gli araldi possono essere scelti prima di iniziare la partita e questo ti permette di pianificare strategie molto precise e diverse a seconda dell’avversario che dovrai affrontare.

L’energia mistica è rappresentata da gemme di plastica. Dopo aver giocato una carta devi prelevare dal tuo pozzo le gemme indicate e posarle su di essa. Le gemme sulla carta indicano il valore di attacco, il valore di difesa e i punti ferita della carta. Di conseguenza una carta con tre gemme, infligge tre danni e può subire tre danni prima di estinguersi, se subisce un danno perde una gemma e quindi da quel momento infligge solo due danni.

Durante la fase del confronto il giocatore di turno gioca le proprie carte, le manda all’attacco e usa i propri prodigi per cercare di sconfiggere le schiere nemiche e costringere il Prime avversario a scendere in campo.
 Alla fine del turno c’è la fase del respiro. I templi, i Prime e alcune altre carte specifiche “respirano” e ridanno energia mistica al proprio pozzo e quindi puoi aggiungere nuove gemme. Poi tocca all’avversario che ripete la stessa sequenza finché uno dei due Prime non viene sconfitto.

Un'altra interessante caratteristica è la possibilità di giocare in squadre, anche con soluzioni “asimmetriche”: uno contro due, due contro tre, due contro 4, ecc. grazie al sistema di gioco che automaticamente si auto bilancia.

Per l’ambientazione è stato scelto il tema mitologico in alternativa all’ormai fin troppo diffuso Fantasy. Attualmente è possibile giocare con tre Pantheon : 
- Antichi Greci
- Antichi Egizi
- Vichinghi 
E’ già in preparazione il panteon giapponese.

CIA: Collect It All is a competitive card game based on the CIA training game Collection Deck. Players take on the role of agents who are collecting intelligence and tackling security threats over multiple rounds.

Each round starts with ten crisis cards in the center of the table. Each crisis has aspects (Political, Military, Economic, Weapons), difficulty, and required number of Techniques. Players start each round with a hand of Intelligence Techniques and Reality Checks.

On their turn, a player can attempt to overcome a crisis by playing a number of Techniques that match the crisis's difficulty and aspects. Then, their opponents have a chance to play Reality Check cards that increase the difficulty of the crisis and the initial player can adapt by playing more cards from their hand. If they still have enough Techniques to overcome the crisis, they take crisis card and earn victory points equal to the number of Techniques used. The game ends when a player has accumulated 10 victory points.

Flipping Zombies is a simple dexterity game in which you must flip bullets at zombie cards to kill them. The game is played by placing the zombie card on the table and the flipping bullet tokens (bottle caps or other tokens) from the edge of the table and trying to hit a targeted portion of the card. If you miss, the zombie deals hits to you. The game is won by killing all zombies or lost by losing all your health points.

Each turn you will draw cards that may be items that can help you such as additional bullets, bandages to add health, or armor that will allow you to reload your ammo. There are several types of zombies including armored zombies and the dreaded chicken zombie!
